questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about fibroids?

options.A: More common in Asians than African-Americans
options.D: Does not usually increase in size during pregnancy

questions.question: Which of the following genes is not associated with leiomyomas?
questions.explanation: MLH1 gene is not associated with leiomyomas. Its mutation leads to endometrial carcinoma.MED12 and HMGA2 are the most common genes associated with leiomyomas. Other genesinvolved are COL4A5-A6 and the gene for fumarate hydratase (FH). FH gene mutation leads tohereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer (HLRCC) syndrome.

questions.question: Leiomyomas create a hyperestrogenic state by all of these mechanisms except:

options.A: Cells contain a greater density of estrogen receptors
options.C: Have higher levels of cytochrome P450 aromatase

questions.explanation: Leiomyomas convert less estradiol to the weaker estrone.624Leiomyomas create a hyperestrogenic environment, which is a requisite for their growth andmaintenance. The hyperestrogenic environment is created by the following mechanisms:• Compared to normal myometrium, leiomyoma cells contain a greater density of estrogenreceptors, which results in greater estradiol binding.•These tumors convert less estradiol to the weaker estrone.• There are higher levels of cytochrome P450 aromatase in leiomyomas compared with normalmyocytes. This specific enzyme catalyzes the conversion of androgens to estrogen.

questions.question: Initially, all fibroids are
questions.explanation: Initially, all fibroids are intramural. Fibroids develop in the myometrium, asintramural/interstitial and then branch out to form the other types.Classification of fibroids based on anatomical location:•• Body (corporeal) fibroids-• Interstitial/intramural fibroids: They are the most common (75%).• Subserosal fibroids: They are the least common (10%). Interstitial fibroids grow outwards toform subserous fibroids and are covered by the peritoneum. These include wandering or parasiticfibroids and broad ligament fibroids.• Submucous fibroids: Interstitial fibroid grows inwards towards the uterine cavity. It is the mostsymptomatic type.• Cervical fibroids

questions.question: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. A hysterectomy was performed andthe following specimen was retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: PedunculatedsubmucousIntramuralIntraligamentary-CervicalTypes of fibroidsSubserosalPedunculatedsubserosalOMARROWSubmucousPedunculatedcervical625The given cut section image showing multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, andwhite-greyish with a whorled appearance is Leiomyoma (Fibroid).Leiomyoma is the most common benign and the most common pelvic tumor in females and ismore common in obese females (hyper-estrogenism). They are mostly asymptomatic and the mostcommon symptom is menorrhagia.Leiomyomas can also present with bleeding areas, cystic degeneration, and calcifications. Theuterine cavity is compressed.The image below different types of uterine fibroids classified according to their locations:PedunculatedsubmucousIntramuralIntraligamentary-CervicalTypes of fibroidsSubserosalPedunculatedsubserosalOMARROWSubmucousPedunculatedcervicalSub-mucous fibroids are the most symptomatic type and intra-mural fibroids are the mostcommon type of uterine fibroids.Other options:Option B: Endometrial cancer presents as a polypoid mass protruding into the uterine cavity or asa diffuse thickening of the endometrium. The cut surface may appear white to yellow and mayshow areas of necrosis or hemorrhage.Option C: Endometrial polyps are usually small and may be single or multiple. Grossly, theyappear as soft, red to pink, often pedunculated (attached by a stalk) masses protruding into theuterine cavity. It presents with heavy cyclic or intermenstrual bleeding, or without complaints asan incidental finding on imaging. Estrogen and progesterone have been implicated in the growthof endometrial polyps, and higher receptor levels are seen compared with the normalendometrium.Option D: In Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna), the uterus may appear bulky andsymmetrically enlarged. On the cut section, the myometrium may appear thickened and may showtiny cystic spaces filled with old blood (chocolate cysts). The preferred treatment is hysterectomy.Localised excision or levonorgestrel IUCD is tried in younger women.The image below shows both the gross and histologic appearances of adenomyosis:626

questions.question: Which of the following symptoms would you not expect in a patient diagnosed with uterinefibroids?
questions.explanation: Menouria and hypomenorrhea are not seen in patients with uterine fibroids. Menouria occurs dueto vesicouterine fistulas. Hypomenorrhea is seen in Asherman's syndrome and due to OCP use.Fibroids present with the following clinical features:• Menstrual symptoms such as:• Menstrual irregularities - heavy menstrual bleeding/menorrhagia which is the most commonsymptom, polymenorrhoea, and intermenstrual bleeding (metrorrhagia)•••• Dysmenorrhea• Postmenopausal bleeding• Abdominal pain• Abdominal distension, mass abdomen•Vaginal discharge•Infertility• Recurrent abortions• Pressure symptoms such as:• Urinary retention• Increased frequency of urination•Constipation• Broad ligament fibroids can cause compression of the ureter leading to hydronephrosis orhydroureter.627

questions.question: 615A patient presented with intermenstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. Which of thefollowing types of fibroid is usually associated with this symptom?
questions.explanation: Intermenstrual bleeding is common with submucous fibroids. Metrorrhagia or intermenstrualbleeding refers to bleeding that occurs during the middle of the menstrual cycle.Metrorrhagia in a woman over 40 years warrants a dilatation and curettage procedure to rule outendometrial cancer. This is associated with fibroids in 3% of cases.Polymenorrhoea in a patient with fibroids occurs when she has polycystic ovaries or pelvicinflammatory disease (PID).Progressive menorrhagia is seen in intramural and submucous myoma due to increasedvascularity, endometrial hyperplasia, and an enlarged uterine cavity.Note: Further the distance of the fibroid from the cavity, lesser is the possibility of menorrhagia.For this reason, subserous and pedunculated fibroids do not cause menorrhagia.

questions.question: A 46-year-old woman presented with heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea. Yoususpect a diagnosis of submucous uterine fibroids. Which of the following investigations willhelp you confirm this?
questions.explanation: Investigations required to identify submucous fibroids include:• USG - most commonly done. Transvaginal USG is useful to assess the location, dimension, andassociated adnexal pathology.•MRI gives better soft tissue details but is not routinely done• Saline infusion sonography and hysteroscopy - help to visualise submucous fibroid more clearly• Laparoscopy - If uterus <12 weeks size and associated pelvic pain and infertility and to detectpelvic endometriosis and tubal pathology.• Uterine curettage - A bump is felt in submucous fibroid during endometrial curettage. Dilatationand curettage is done in patients presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.Hysterosalpingography – A filling defect is seen.-CT abdomen is not very useful for the identification of submucous fibroids. These cannot bevisualised on colposcopy either.The image below shows the ultrasonographic appearance of a submucous fibroid (asterisk):628The image given below shows hysteroscopic view of a submucous fibroid:

questions.question: An adnexal mass seen on ultrasound in a 38-year-old woman was diagnosed to be asecondary broad ligament fibroid. Which of the following is true about the same?

options.A: It arises from the broad ligament
options.B: The uterine vessels always lie medial to it
options.C: The ureter always lies lateral to it
options.D: It is also known as true broad ligament fibroid

questions.explanation: The ureter and uterine vessels lie lateral to a secondary broad ligament fibroid.There are 2 types of broad ligament fibroids:Primary broad ligament fibroid:• It is also known as true broad ligament fibroid.•The arise from:• Uterosacral ligament• Round ligament629• Tissues in the broad ligament• Relations:•• The uterine vessels lie medial to it.The ureter is usually beneath the fibroid. However, it can be present anywhere in relation to it.Secondary broad ligament fibroid:••It is also known as false broad ligament fibroid.They arise from the lateral wall of the uterus or cervix, but grow laterally, between the two layersof the broad ligament.• Relations the uterine vessels and ureter lie lateral to it.-

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect about fibroids?

options.B: Hyaline degeneration begins at the centre

questions.explanation: Fibroid calcification begins at the periphery and spreads inwards along the vessels.A typical myoma is a well-circumscribed tumor with a pseudo-capsule and firm in consistency. Itscut surface has a whorled appearance.The vessels that supply blood to the tumor lie in the capsule and send radial branches into thetumor. Therefore, the central portion of the tumour receives the least blood supply, anddegeneration is noticeable early in this part of the tumour. However, fibroid calcification begins atthe periphery.The image given below show the gross appearance of fibroids.RIC 129 10 11 12 11314The below image shows the histological appearance of fibroids.630

questions.question: A patient with a history of miscarriage underwent a myomectomy. The specimen is shownbelow. Where does the degenerative change shown here begin from?
questions.explanation: The given specimen shows red degeneration of fibroid. Degeneration is most likely to start fromthe centre of the fibroid.In a fibroid, centre of the tumor is the least vascular part and hence degeneration is morecommon here. The only exception is calcareous degeneration where phosphates and carbonates oflime are deposited in the periphery along the course of the vessels.

questions.question: A 44-year-old woman presenting with acute abdominal pain had previously been diagnosedwith uterine fibroids. Which of the following complications is most unlikely to have occurredhere?
questions.explanation: Hyaline degeneration of fibroids is unlikely here as it is usually painless and presents as anabdominal mass causing distension and heaviness.Acute pain in fibroids is seen in the case of:•• Fibroid torsion•Hemorrhage into the fibroid• Red degeneration• Sarcomatous change seen in postmenopausal women.-

questions.question: A primigravida presented with severe abdominal pain and fever at 28 weeks of gestation.Ultrasound reveals a healthy fetus in utero and a large submucosal fibroid with multiple,617hyperechoic areas within. Blood investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. What isthe diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of red degeneration of fibroid.It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. The gross appearance is describedas follows:631• Fishy odor• Thrombosis of subcapsular vessels and vessels within the fibroid• Purplish-red color due to diffusion of blood pigments from the thrombosed vessels.Red degeneration presents with acute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations revealleukocytosis and a raised ESR. On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic withinthe fibroid.The image given below shows the MRI appearance of red degeneration of fibroidsBOption B: Torsion of subserous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen, butfever and leukocytosis are absent.Option C: Infection is more common in puerperium and presents with blood-stained vaginaldischarge.Option D: Sarcomatous changes occur very rarely, and are unlikely in patients <40 years of age.They are more commonly seen in post-menopausal women.

questions.question: A 34-year old woman with a history of fibroids presented with 1.5 months of amenorrhea.UPT is positive. Which of the following complications will you not expect in this patient?
questions.explanation: Fetal malformations have not been recorded to occur due to fibroids.Pregnancy complications due to fibroids are:• Increased risk of abortion or miscarriage• Preterm labor• Abnormal presentation•Fibroid degeneration (Red degenaration)• Accidental hemorrhage•Dystocic labor632• Postpartum hemorrhage• Puerperal sepsis•• Uterine inversion

questions.question: Which of the following changes are not seen in fibroids?
questions.explanation: Squamous metaplasia is not seen in fibroids.

questions.question: CT pelvis of a woman with fibroids is shown below. Which type of degeneration is seen here?
questions.explanation: The given image shows a womb-stone appearance on CT, suggestive of calcific degeneration of a fibroid. These are also called calcareous myomas and are seen in old patients with long-standing myomas. This occurs due to the deposition of calcium phosphates and calcium carbonates in the periphery of the fibroid, along the course of the vessels. It is easily visualized on radiography.

questions.question: What is the least common secondary change seen in fibroids?
questions.explanation: Sarcomatous change is the least common secondary change in fibroids. Its incidence is <0.5%.Sarcomatous change leads to the development of malignant leiomyosarcomas. This is seen inpostmenopausal women and is rare in women <40 years of age. Intramural and submucoustumors have a higher potential for sarcomatous change than subserous tumors.Its gross appearance is described as follows:• Soft consistency• Yellowish-grey•Hemorrhagic spots seenRadiology shows dark, irregular areas and air levels within the fibroid. These are indicative ofsarcomatous change.The image given below shows the CT appearance of a large fibroid that has undergonesarcomatous change. The image on the right shows a fluid level within the tumor.633B

questions.question: A 46-year-old woman presents with a lower abdominal mass for the past 2 years. She hadundergone uterine artery embolisation for fibroids 5 years ago. Ultrasound showed ahomogeneous mass near the uterine fundus. On exploratory laparotomy, the mass wasobserved to be attached to the greater omentum and it was excised. Histopathology of themass is shown below. What is your diagnosis?619
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of a parasitic fibroid. The given histopathological imageshows interlacing bundles of uniform spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with blunted nuclei thatare characteristic of a fibroid.A parasitic fibroid or a wandering fibroid gets cut off from its uterine origin and derives its bloodsupply from the vessels of the organ it is attached to. Thus, it can continue to grow in spite ofuterine artery embolisation. It is managed by complete resection.Option A: Pedunculated fibroids have a pedicle with which they're attached to the myometrium.Option C: Leiomyosarcoma commonly presents in postmenopausal women with sudden increasein size and postmenopausal bleeding. It would show nuclear atypia on histology.Option D: Disseminated intraperitoneal leiomyomatosis involves large areas of sub peritonealsurfaces. It is seen during pregnancy and while on oral contraceptives.

questions.question: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops severe acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks ofgestation. There is no history of fever and the WBC count is 8000 cells/mL. The most likelydiagnosis is:
questions.explanation: The given scenario of severe acute abdominal pain without fever/leucocytosis in a pregnantwoman with a fibroid is suggestive of fibroid torsion.The incidence of fibroid in pregnancy is about 1 in 1,000. Due to increased vascularity inpregnancy, the fibroid increases in size and becomes softer. The torsion is seen in the subserouspedunculated fibroid where the venous return is blocked at its site of attachment in the uterus.This leads to severe acute abdominal pain. Due to the complication being more local thansystemic, fever or leucocytosis are generally not seen.A transvaginal ultrasonogram is immediately done to detect the position and size of the fibroid,which is followed by laparotomic myomectomy as a part of emergency surgical management.634Other options:Option A: Red degeneration of fibroid is seen commonly in the second half of pregnancy orpuerperium. It is due to a hemorrhagic infarction of the tissue and typically presents as acute focalabdominal pain with fever and leucocytosis. Treatment is usually conservative with bed rest,analgesics, and sedatives.Option B: Preterm labor is where the labor starts before 37 completed weeks. It is characterized bytrue labor pain. The abdominal pain is slowly increasing in intensity and duration and is alsoaccompanied by show (expulsion of the cervical mucus plug). There are intervals betweenepisodes of contractions where the patient doesn't complain of abdominal pain.

questions.question: A primigravida at 24 weeks presents to you for a routine antenatal checkup. On ultrasound,you incidentally note the presence of two 3x3cm submucosal fibroids. How will you managethis case?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of an uncomplicated fibroid during pregnancy. These aremanaged conservatively.Surgery is only indicated in the case of a pedunculated fibroid undergoes torsion.

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman presented with menorrhagia and increased frequency of micturition.Ultrasound abdomen shows the following picture. Which of the following drugs is not used inthe management of her condition?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario and ultrasound image showing a well-defined, heterogeneous hypoechoicmass are suggestive of a uterine fibroid. Misoprostol does not help to reduce the size of the fibroidand so is not recommended for its management.Medical management of fibroids helps to reduce their size. The drugs used in therapy are asfollows:• Antiprogesterone - Mifepristone / RU-486• GnRH analogs•Agonists goserelin, leuprorelin, nafarelin, buserelin-• Antagonists - cetrorelix, ganirelix•Levonorgestrel releasing intrauterine system•Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM) - Asoprisnil• Danazol - usually not used due to androgenic side effects.

questions.question: A patient diagnosed with leiomyoma was prescribed an intranasal spray to managedisease. Which of the following drugs is it unlikely to contain?
questions.explanation: The nasal spray is unlikely to contain histrelin, as it is only available as a subcutaneous implant.GnRH analogues are used to treat leiomyomas. Intranasal preparations are available forleuprolide, nafarelin, and buserelin. However, leuprolide has maximal action as an intramuscularinjection.635GnRH analogue therapy in fibroids is given as follows:• Leuprolide acetate (Lupron) - given intramuscularly. It is also available as an intranasal spray,but isn't commonly used.• Goserelin (Zoladex) - subcutaneous depot implant••Triptorelin (Trelstar) IM injection• Nafarelin and buserelin - given as intranasal sprays bd• Histrelin - available as subcutaneous implants.

questions.question: her621A pregnant woman was diagnosed with red degeneration of fibroid at 26 weeks of gestation.What is the next step in her management?
questions.explanation: Red degeneration of fibroid is managed conservatively with bed rest and analgesics.It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. Red degeneration presents withacute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR.On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic within the fibroid.

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presented with anemia due to heavy menstrual bleeding in spite ofmedical management of fibroids. She was posted for a myomectomy as she wanted to havechildren in the future. Which of the following is not an indication for this procedure?
questions.explanation: Red degeneration is not an indication of myomectomy. It is conservatively managed.Myomectomy is indicated in the following:•Symptoms compromising the quality of life such as:• Heavy menstrual bleeding, causing anemia• Pelvic pain••Urinary symptoms and ureteric obstruction.The patient is unwilling for hysterectomy• The patient wishes to preserve childbearing function•Fibroids causing infertility

questions.question: Which of the following modalities is not used for the treatment of leiomyomas?
questions.explanation: Ultrasound-guided transcervical metroplasty is not used in the treatment of leiomyomas. It isused for the resection of the uterine septum.Uterine artery embolization/Uterine fibroid embolization (UAE/UFE) is an angiographicinterventional procedure that delivers polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) microspheres or other syntheticparticulate emboli into both uterine arteries thus producing ischemia and necrosis. The vesselsserving leiomyomas have a larger caliber, hence these microspheres are preferentially directed tothe tumors, thus sparing the surrounding myometrium.636Nd:YAG myolysis is laparoscopic myolysis performed with an Nd:YAG laser. It causes coagulationof a subserous fibroid.The below image shows uterine artery embolization.CatheterUterinearteryFemoralartery-MUterine artery embolizationUterinearteryCatheterParticlesoccluding arteryOMARROWMagnetic Resonance guided Focused Ultrasound (MRgFUS) is also called MR-guidedhigh-intensity focused ultrasound (MR-HIFU).Ultrasound energy is focused to heat and incite coagulative necrosis in selected myomas.Concurrent MR imaging enables precise targeting and provides real-time tissue temperaturefeedback to limit surrounding thermal injury.The given image shows MRgFUS.Magnetic resonance-guided focusedultrasound surgery (MRgFUS)MRI unitImaging coil

questions.question: The following procedure was planned for a patient with uterine fibroids. Which of thefollowing statements is false about this procedure?622UterinearteryCatheterParticlesoccluding arteryOMARROW

options.A: Can be done in nulliparous women
options.B: Ovarian failure is one of the complications

questions.explanation: MyomaUltrasound transducerOMARROWFoucused ultrasound energy637The given image shows uterine artery embolization (UAE). UAE cannot be done in nulliparouswomen as embolization of ovarian vessels can cause ovarian failure and premature menopause.Under local sedation, bilateral UAE is approached through percutaneous femoral catheterization.Embolization is done by releasing polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), gel foam particles or metal coils intothe uterine artery.638
